By Amanda Becker
| LOS ANGELES

LOS ANGELES Democrat Hillary Clinton said on a late-night television show on Monday that sometimes she feels she is in an ""alternative universe"" in the U.S. presidential race against Republican Donald Trump.""I do feel sometimes like this campaign has entered into an alternative universe
column2: Clinton said on ABC's Jimmy Kimmel Live. ""I have to step into the alternative reality
column3: answer questions about am I alive
column4: how much longer will I be alive.""Clinton was for the first time responding to allegations made by Trump and some of his backers that she is suffering health problems that could be problematic in the White House should she win the Nov. 8 election.Both Clinton and Trump have released notes from doctors declaring them physically fit for the presidency.Kimmel asked Clinton to open a jar of pickles as a test of her strength. She did so successfully.

column1: This has become one of their themes. Take my pulse while I'm talking to you - make sure I'm alive
column2: Clinton said to Kimmel of the health rumors.Clinton said that sometimes Trump's remarks about her - such as a recent charge that President Barack Obama and Clinton co-founded the Islamic State
column3: which he later said was sarcasm - go beyond personal attacks and become harmful to U.S. national security.""There's enough evidence now that when Trump talks the way he talks it actually helps the terrorists
column4: Clinton said. ""I think it's crazy
column5: but I think it's also harmful.""

column1: Clinton said she had begun preparing for the three presidential debates scheduled in September and October.""I want to take it seriously
column2: Clinton said. ""But you've got to be prepared for
column3: like wacky stuff that comes at you and I am drawing on my experience in elementary school.""

column1: Clinton brushed off the possible release of an additional 14
column2: 900 emails that the FBI found when investigating her use of a private email server as secretary of state.""My emails are so boring
column3: Clinton said. ""What's a few more?""The U.S. State Department has already reviewed some 30
column4: 068 emails from her 2009-2013 tenure and released most of them
column5: amounting to some 55
column6: 000 pages.  (Reporting by Amanda Becker; Editing by Michael Perry)"	['Clinton'

column1: AKRON

column7: got favors from the State Department during Hillary Clinton's 2009-2013 tenure as the country's top diplomat.Trump faulted both the Justice Department and Federal Bureau of Investigation for not indicting Clinton over her use of a private email server as secretary of state. FBI Director James Comey cited her careless handling of classified emails but opted not to prosecutor her.""The Justice Department is required to appoint a special prosecutor because it has proved to be

column1: 3	3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-email-idUSKCN10X1A1	Judge orders State Department to review 14
column2: 900 Clinton emails	"

column1: By Ginger Gibson and Arshad Mohammed
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON A judge ordered the U.S. State Department on Monday to review for possible release 14
column2: 900 of Hillary Clinton's emails and attachments that the FBI found when investigating her use of a private email server as secretary of state.The judge also scheduled a Sept. 23 hearing on when to release the emails
column3: a deadline that raises the possibility some will become public before the Nov. 8 presidential election between Democrat Clinton and her Republican rival
column4: Donald Trump.Questions about her email practices as secretary of state have dogged Clinton's White House run and triggered a Federal Bureau of Investigation probe that found she was ""extremely careless"" with sensitive information by using a private server but recommended against bringing charges.State Department spokesman Mark Toner told reporters it was still reviewing the 14
column5: 900 documents and it was unclear how many were personal or work-related. He also said it was unclear how many may duplicate those already released but that there were ""likely to be quite a few"" not previously disclosed.The department has already culled through some 30
column6: 068 of  Clinton emails from her 2009-2013 tenure as secretary of state and released most of them
column9: 000 emails were found to contain classified information.The disclosure of further emails could provide more fodder for opponents who have seized on the issue to argue that Clinton is untrustworthy.Clinton
column10: who leads Trump in opinion polls
column11: has said she did not compromise classified information and used a private server for convenience. She later apologized
column12: saying: ""I take responsibility.""The order by U.S. District Court Judge James Boasberg
column13: who is overseeing a group of lawsuits seeking to make Clinton's emails public
column14: came the day a conservative watchdog group
column16: made public a batch of Clinton's emails obtained through a lawsuit.

column1: Judicial Watch said the emails showed donors to the Clinton family's charitable foundation seeking access to her during the period she was secretary of state.Toner said the State Department believed there was ""no impropriety"" in foundation officials seeking to meet Clinton
column2: saying any secretary of state or aides get such requests from a wide range of people.The 14
column3: 900 documents referred to by Boasberg are believed to include emails not included among those Clinton previously turned over to the State Department after her use of a private email server and private email account became public.""This number reflects both non-record (meaning personal) and record materials (meaning work related)
column4: said a U.S. official who spoke on condition of anonymity.Some of the emails were found on the servers of people with whom Clinton or her staff was communicating.

column1: 'TRYING TO PIN IT ON ME'
Former Secretary of State Colin Powell dismissed reports over the weekend that Clinton told federal investigators that it was at his suggestion that she used a personal email account
column2: according to a media report.Powell
column3: who served as the nation's top diplomat from 2001 to 2005 under Republican President George W. Bush
column4: told People magazine that while he did send Clinton a memo about his own email practices
column5: Clinton had already chosen to use personal email rather than a government account while she had the job.

column1: Her people have been trying to pin it on me. ... The truth is
column2: she was using (the private email server) for a year before I sent her a memo telling her what I did
column3: Powell told People on Saturday.  The New York Times reported last week that Clinton told federal investigators that Powell had suggested she use personal email for unclassified email when the two spoke over dinner. The conversation occurred ""in the early months"" of Clinton's tenure at the State Department
column4: the Times said
column5: citing a forthcoming book by journalist Joe Conason that first reported the dinner exchange.Representatives for Powell
column6: in a separate statement to NBC News
column7: said he had no recollection of the conversation with Clinton.""He did write former Secretary Clinton an email memo describing his use of his personal AOL email account for unclassified messages and how it vastly improved communications within the State Department
column8: his office told NBC on Friday.The email exchange occurred in 2009
column9: according to the Times.Powell and aides to his successor as secretary of state in the Bush administration
column11: received some classified information via personal email accounts
column12: Reuters has reported. Clinton's additional use of a personal computer server at her home
column15: an internal watchdog found. (Additional reporting by Susan Heavey; Editing by Frances Kerry and Peter Cooney)"	['Clinton'

5	5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-tax-inversions-idUSKCN10X24F	Republicans urge U.S. Treasury to overhaul tax inversion proposals	"
By David Morgan
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON Republican lawmakers called on U.S. Treasury Secretary Jack Lew on Monday to overhaul proposed regulations intended to crack down on American companies that try to reduce their U.S. taxes by rebasing abroad in a process known as inversion.In separate letters
column2: top Republicans on the Senate Finance Committee and House Ways and Means Committee warned on Monday that Treasury is moving too quickly to adopt regulations to prevent overseas mergers known as tax inversions
column3: in which U.S. firms relocate their headquarters in countries with lower corporate tax rates.""If the proposed regulations are not completely overhauled
column4: they would damage our economy
column5: increase the barriers to investment for American businesses and innovators
column6: and interfere with the growth of ... good-paying jobs
column7: said a letter to Lew from Ways and Means Committee Chairman Kevin Brady and other Republicans on the panel. ""We cannot allow this to happen

column1: The regulations were proposed in April and Treasury has indicated that it intends to move swiftly to finalize the rules. Industry leaders fear the rules could be in place permanently as early as September.One new inversion rule
column2: which has already been imposed on a temporary basis
column3: was challenged this month in federal court by business groups including the U.S. Chamber of Commerce.Brady and other Republicans including Senate Finance Committee Chairman Orrin Hatch trained their sights on proposals that industry officials say would swamp business with new red tape and cripple internal cash management operations at companies that are not involved in tax inversions.

column1: The only prudent way to move forward -- given the complexity of the subject matter
column2: given the many significant substantive concerns that have been pointed out
column3: and given the procedural irregularities -- is to issue the regulations in re-proposed form
column4: Hatch said in his letter to Lew. The proposed debt-equity rule is aimed at stopping a practice known as earnings stripping
column5: which occurs when a newly inverted company eludes U.S. taxes by moving profits overseas as tax-deductible interest payments on loans to its foreign parent.

column1: Treasury has proposed requiring debt interest payments to be converted into stock dividends
column2: which are not tax deductible.Critics say the regulations
column3: as proposed
column4: could play havoc with the internal finances of a range of unsuspecting businesses
column5: from multinational corporations to limited partnerships.   (Reporting by David Morgan; Editing by Bill Rigby)"	['Hatch']	[]
